awd_titl_txt: Design and Engineering of Enhanced Ribosomes with Universal Protein-Folding Capabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
If proteins are overproduced, they may fold incorrectly. This often results in the formation of an insoluble protein mass called an inclusion body (IB). Harvesting functioning protein from IBs is difficult. Avoiding their formation is important and might be achieved by modifying the protein synthesis machinery, the ribosome. Computer simulations will suggest effective changes in the ribosome, and those changes will be made and evaluated. Graduate and undergraduate students will perform simulations and experiments. The PI and some graduate students will also be heavily involved in a conference which fosters participation of Chicanos and Latino Americans in science. 
	

The production of large quantities of soluble bioactive proteins in bacteria is still problematic. The goal of this research project is to overcome the protein folding problem by reengineering the bacterial (E. coli) ribosomal machinery. Specifically, slowing the rate of translation termination, thereby reducing the rate of fully-synthesized protein ejected from the ribosomal exit tunnel. Intrinsic chaperone-like properties of the bacterial ribosome will be enhanced. A combination of computer simulations, CRISPR-Cas9-assisted recombineering, and fluorescence-based and colorimetric solubility assays will be employed. Accomplishing the goals of this project will benefit science and engineering alike. It will provide a vector for training the next generation of genetic engineers and chemical biologists. They will be able to combine rational and stochastic approaches, and integrate kinetic simulations, computational design and experimental genetic engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
PROJECT OUTCOMES


Design and Engineering of Enhanced Ribosomes with Universal

Protein-Folding Capabilities

PI: Silvia Cavagnero

Proteins are essential microscopic machines for life on earth. Living cells could not function without a myriad of proteins performing wonderful, highly specialized and diverse functions. Amazingly, protein activity is highly coordinated in space and time, across living organisms. Much of this coordination is achieved via the help of other proteins.

One of the most important requirements for functional proteins is the attainment of a highly organized three-dimensional structure, known as the proper “fold”. The folded shape of proteins enables scientists to study them to better understand various aspects of cellular function and mechanism. In addition, and most importantly, properly 3D-shaped proteins are necessary in biotechnology, to improve food quality, to generate new sources of energy, and to create novel bio-materials targeted to the improvement of people’s every-day-life. In summary, folded proteins bear an enormous potential to expand the toolkit of available sources of food texture, microorganism-generated energy, bioelasticity and desirable mechanical/rheological properties. These remarkable tunable properties of folded proteins can, in turn, be readily exploited in basic-science, biotechnology, the generation of bioinspired materials, and other everyday-life and industrial applications.

The goal of this research has been to understand and modify the cellular machinery responsible for the generation of folding proteins, so that the formation of undesirable mis-shaped entities known as “inclusion bodies” can be prevented and altogether avoided. Inclusion bodies are undesirable because they are large, insoluble, mis-shaped, and extremely hard to convert into a the properly folded protein state. Yet, unfortunately, inclusion bodies often get generated when one attempts to produce large quantities of folded proteins via recombinant DNA technologies.

At the Intellectual Merit level, the investigations carried out in the Cavagnero group led to the development of new strategies to avoid inclusion-body formation. More specifically, studies carried out with the support of this grant led to the discovery that the protein-making machinery, known as the ribosome, is much more than a protein builder. It is also a protein folder. We also elucidated how helper proteins known as molecular chaperones can enable the generation of more efficiently folded proteins by retarding the formation of undesirable mis-shaped proteins known as “aggregates”. We discovered how to turn the important Hsp70 molecular chaperone on and off, by developing a novel Hsp70 inhibitor. Finally, we made significant progress towards the implementation of an exciting new technology to slow down protein ejection from the ribosome. In this way, we have been able to increase the available time of newly generated proteins to achieve their proper folded state, before the risk of protein aggregation takes over. In summary, there is a bright future for the control and efficient production of large amounts of properly folded proteins in basic science and biotechnology, thanks to the studies carried out as a result of the funding of this research project.

As far as the Broader Impacts of this research are concerned, a number of important milestones have also been achieved, as summarized below.

First, several undergraduate students have been doing research on this project in the PI’s group. Several of them have been publication co-authors of the publications resulting from this work, including a first-author publication arising from the work of Chelsea Chen, a former undergraduate student who is now pursuing graduate studies at Case Western Research University.

Second, the PI has been promoting racial and ethnic diversity in science by participating and organizing a variety of activities. She has been the Chair of the Climate/Diversity Committee at the Univ. Wisconsin-Madison Dept of Chemistry and is the Co-founder and co-organizer of the Chemistry OPportunitieS (CHOPS) campus pre-visit event for prospective underrepresented graduate students exploring options at the Univ. of Wisconsin-Madison. The PI has been a poster judge, mentor, speaker, and recruiter at the SACNAS National Conference, during each year of the project, by actively fostering participation of Chicanos and American Indians to science. The PI has organized Scientific Sessions in Biophysics and Chemical Biology at SACNAS, again during each year of the project, to encourage underrepresented students to embrace cross-disciplinary biologically related research.

Third, the PI developed new interactive lectures in Physical Chemistry and Biothermodynamics/Kinetics to help students embrace a number of specific contemporary hot topics in this field. The special topics addressed in these new interactive lectures include a deep understanding of the hydrophobic effect; protein’s response to pressure, temperature and denaturing agents; biomolecular condensates and, last but not least, free-energy coupling in biology and biotechnology.


Last Modified: 04/14/2024
Modified by: Silvia Cavagnero
